ePortfolio

Cirrus Cloud Effects on Land Use Classification of Multi-temporal Landsat 8 Data: a Case Study using Hierarchical/Multilevel Models

Gregory B. Anderson and Randolph H. Wynne

Cirrus clouds are widespread across the globe and cover up to thirty percent of the Earth’s surface at any given time. These high, wispy clouds can be problematic for remote sensing for many reasons: (1) they are harder to identify than water-based clouds due to the fact they are partially transmissive, (2) their radiance variation is large and shows strong band dependence, and (3) their shape is generally larger and more diverse than water-based clouds. Landsat 8 was designed to include a new cirrus band (band 9; 1.36-1.39 m) on the Operation Land Imager that attempts to detect light that is reflected by these high-altitude clouds that are not otherwise visible, but methods to incorporate this information into classification procedures have been slow to develop. In this study, we further explore the effect of cirrus cloud interruption on land use classification and develop a method that accounts for cirrus cloud contamination of band reflectance using a hierarchical/multilevel model. Results from a sample Landsat 8 multitemporal stack in Virginia, USA demonstrate that cirrus cloud interruption can alter the spectral signature of most informational classes when present, and this effect can cause misclassification of Landsat scenes using traditional multinomial classification approaches. Our hierarchical multinomial modeling approach, which estimates error due to cirrus cloud contamination in conjunction with the classification routine, significantly improved classification of the sample scene, especially in areas with high cirrus cloud interruption, where accuracy increased from 88.6% to 98.2%. These results emphasize the importance of the additional cirrus band on the Operation Land Imager and the value of accounting for cirrus clouds in land use classification methods.

Accounting for Imperfect Detection and Spatiotemporal Autocorrelation in a BACI Design to Monitor the Endangered Roanoke Logperch

Gregory B. Anderson, James H. Roberts, and Paul L. Angermeier

The Before-After-Control Impact (BACI) design is often used to monitor populations simultaneously in both a control and an impact area, to distinguish effects of specific anthropogenic disturbances (e.g., construction, remediation) from other uncontrolled effects. However, this design can be biased by several factors that alter or weaken the inferences to be drawn. First, the BACI design contains spatial and/or temporal pseudoreplication. Population counts at multiple sites and/or times are often treated as independent samples even though target populations are rarely distributed uniformly or randomly over time and space. Instead, populations typically exhibit aggregate patterns, gradients, or other spatiotemporal structures. These structures violate the implicit assumption of independent and identically distributed errors present in most analytical methods, thus underestimating standard errors and increasing the risk of Type I error. Second, inference in BACI designs can be confounded by imperfect detection of individuals, which can underestimate abundance and the effects of covariates and can also exhibit autocorrelation over time or space. Using data collected on the federally endangered Roanoke logperch (Percina rex) from 1996 to 2012 at 12 sites across 13 river km, we demonstrate one method for accounting for spatiotemporal autocorrelation in logperch abundance and detection probability to evaluate the impacts of the Roanoke River Flood Reduction Project (RRFRP), a suite of channel and floodplain modifications to the mainstem Roanoke River. We adopt a zero-inflated negative binomial N-mixture model to estimate logperch abundance in the presence of detection error and utilize Moran’s Eigenvector Maps to account for spatiotemporal autocorrelation in both abundance and detection. Our results suggest that observed logperch captures demonstrated significant spatial and temporal structures in detection and abundance; however, detection patterns were more complex, requiring a larger number of eigenvectors. Estimates of abundance and detection varied dramatically among years and sites, with detection probabilities as low as 0.04 to as high as 0.68 and estimates of abundances between 3 and 53 individuals at a site. Although we found little to no evidence of an impact from the RRFRP, our approach facilitated the comparison of biologically interpretable models representing hypotheses regarding both detection and abundance that would not be possible using traditional analyses for BACI designs. Our analysis suggests that abundance varied by season and that detection was negatively correlated to river flow during sampling.

Accounting for Euclidean and Hydrologic Distance in a Geostatistical Model of a Fluvial Fish Distribution

Gregory B. Anderson and Jian Huang

Rigorus species’ distribution models (SDMs) are critical tools in biodiversity conservation and resource management. However, map-based species’ distributions often exhibit spatial autocorrelation due to the similarity of environmental features, the scale of biological processes, or unaccounted spatial variation in the biological response within study sites close in proximity. Therefore, approaches that evaluate a species’ response purely along environmental gradients in a SDM might only capture a portion of the factors or mechanisms that drive the species’ distribution and future shift. Additionally, violating the assumption of independent and identical-distributed errors in linear models yields biased parameter estimation and inflated false rejection in significance testing of habitat-distribution relationships. Conventionally, Euclidean-distance covariance structures have been incorporated into generalized linear models, conditional autoregressive models, or simultaneous autoregressive models. However, these strategies have been shown to poorly represent the spatial distribution of biological responses in stream networks. In this study, we utilized a mixed-model moving-average approach to predict the spatial distribution of a fluvial fish species (Percina crassa) with the upper Yadkin River system of Virginia and North Carolina. Specifically, we present how spatial pattern and autocorrelation vary under different covariance structures based on several proximity matrices (Euclidean and different types of fluvial distance), and we compare a series of generalized linear mixed models representing non-competing hypothesis regarding spatial patterns using leave-one-out cross validation.

Assessing the Effects of Single Versus Multiple Flow Path Direction Methods on Species-environmental Relationships and Estimated Species Distributions

Gregory B. Anderson

By relating spatial distributional patterns of species to environmental predictor variables, species distribution models (SDMs) provide a framework to predict the response of a species to environmental covariates and to predict the occurrence or abundance of a species throughout a landscape. With an increase in the availability of data collected from Geographic Information Systems and remote sensing, environmental covariates used to model species distributions are commonly remotely derived. However, the assumptions and uncertainties of spatially derived data sets are often not explored. In order to evaluate the effect of different spatial analyst procedures available on the estimation of fluvial species-environmental relationships, this study investigated the sensitivity associated with using single versus multiple flow path direction methods for automatic watershed delineation in a GIS. Results demonstrated that catchment area and land use area estimated can differ dramatically depending on the delineation procedure used; however, in this study, the increase in area of each land class were proportional and more advanced watershed delineation algorithms demonstrated only slightly higher predictability than simpler ones. Although regression coefficients estimated with different delineation procedures showed only minor changes, the project area occupied by species could be drastic for headwater specialists.

Community Inference Using Hierarchical Multi-Species Logistic Regression Models

Gregory B. Anderson, Brandon Peoples and Craig Roghair

Species distributional models (SDMs) are powerful tools for making inferences on relationships between species and their environments. For many taxa, multiple species are encountered when sampling for a species of interest (e.g., fishes, birds, macroinvertebrates, etc.). However, standard SDMs ignore the additional information that non-focal species provide, and cannot predict occurrences within the context of biotic communities. Although multiple species are seldom included in SDMs, recent advances within the occupancy estimation literature have provided a framework to extend SDMs to multiple species using hierarchical models. In contrast to monitoring species individually, the multi-species approach allows for the “borrowing” of information from similar species to improve model estimates, especially for rare or ‘data poor’ species (DeWan and Zipkin et al. 2010). In addition, this approach provides a better understanding of the aggregated response of groups of species or the entire community to changes over a landscape. In this paper, we used a data set of fluvial fish occurrences to investigate the strengths and limitations associated with both the single- and multiple-species SDM approaches. These data are drawn from a typical data set collected within a single-season of sampling 40 stream sites. Our specific objectives were to: 1) develop a typical single species SDM, 2) develop a community level SDM, 3) investigate the effect of additional grouping terms (e.g. reproductive guild, family, parental care) on the community level model, and 4) compare the benefits and limitations of each approach.

Gregory B. Anderson
